searchDocs.title: MDX Blog Post
searchDocs.content: Blog posts support Docusaurus Markdown features, such as MDX. tip Use the power of React to create interactive blog posts. <button onClick={() => alert('button clicked!')}>Click me!</button> Click me!

searchDocs.title: Welcome
searchDocs.content: Docusaurus blogging features are powered by the blog plugin. Simply add Markdown files (or folders) to the blog directory. Regular blog authors can be added to authors.yml. The blog post date can be extracted from filenames, such as: 2019-05-30-welcome.md2019-05-30-welcome/index.md A blog post folder can be convenient to co-locate blog post images: The blog supports tags as well! And if you don't want a blog: just delete this directory, and use blog: false in your Docusaurus config.

searchDocs.title: Sum​
searchDocs.content: Substrait definition Calculates the sum of numeric values, if there are no rows a NULL value is returned. if a value is non numeric such as a string or null, those values are ignored.

searchDocs.title: SQL Usage​
searchDocs.content: SELECT sum(column1) FROM ...

searchDocs.title: Sum0​
searchDocs.content: Substrait definition Calculates the sum of numeric values, if there are no rows a + value is returned. if a value is non numeric such as a string or null, those values are ignored.

searchDocs.title: SQL Usage​
searchDocs.content: SELECT sum0(column1) FROM ...

searchDocs.title: Source​
searchDocs.content: The SQL Server Source allows Flowtide to fetch rows and updates from a SQL Server table. There is one prerequisite for this connector to work: info Change tracking must be enabled on the table. Without change tracking, Flowtide wont be able to find updates on the table. There are plans to allow the source to run in batch mode where it computes the delta inside of the connector, but that is not yet available. The SQL Server Source can be added to the 'ReadWriteFactory' with the following line: factory.AddSqlServerSource("your regexp on table names", () => connectionString);  The connection string must be set as a function, since the idea is that the connection string might change, from say a system such asHashicorp Vault. The source uses the following logic to fetch data into the stream:  The source will retry fetching data in-case of a SQL Server error, as long as it can reconnect to the database. It will mark the operator as unhealthy, but it will not trigger a stream restart. If the operator cannot reconnect to the SQL Server, it will trigger a full stream restart.

searchDocs.title: Sink​
searchDocs.content: The SQL Server Sink implements the grouped write operator. This means that all rows are grouped by a primary key, thus all sink tables must have a primary key defined. info All SQL Server Sink tables must have a primary key defined. The primary key must also be in the query that fills the table. Its implementation waits fully until the stream has reached a steady state at a time T until it writes data to the database. This means that its table output can always be traced back to a state from the source systems. To use the SQL Server Sink add the following line to the ReadWriteFactory: factory.AddSqlServerSink("your regexp on table names", () => connectionString);  As with the SQL Server Source, the connection string is returned by a function to enable dynamic connection strings. The sink inserts data into SQL Server by creating a temporary table, which follows the table structure of the destination with an added operation metadata column. The data is inserted into the temporary table using Bulk Copy. This allows for fast binary insertion into the temporary table. After data has been inserted into the temporary table, a merge into statement is run that merges data into the destination table. After all data has been merged, the temporary table is cleared of all data. danger If there are multiple rows in the result with the same primary key, only the latest seen row will be inserted into the destination table.

searchDocs.title: SQL Table Provider​
searchDocs.content: The SQL table provider is added to the SQL plan builder which will try and look after used tables in its configured SQL Server. It provides metadata information about what the column names are in the table. To use the table provider add the following line to the Sql plan builder: sqlBuilder.AddSqlServerProvider(() => connectionString);

searchDocs.title: Count​
searchDocs.content: Substrait definition Counts all rows in a query. This function takes no parameters, the implementation of count with a column name is not yet implemented.

searchDocs.title: SQL Usage​
searchDocs.content: SELECT count(*) FROM ...

searchDocs.title: Add​
searchDocs.content: Substrait definition Add takes two parameters and does an addition of the two values. Add depends on the input types on what result it will give: Left type	Right type	OutputInteger	Integer	Integer Integer	Float	Float Float	Float	Float Non numeric	Integer	Null num numeric	Float	Null Non numeric	Non numeric	Null Only numeric inputs will return a result, otherwise it will return null.

searchDocs.title: SQL usage​
searchDocs.content: In SQL the add function is called using the plus operator: SELECT column1 + 13 FROM ...

searchDocs.title: Subtract​
searchDocs.content: Substrait definition Subtract takes two parameters and does a subtraction of the two values. Subtract depends on the input types on what result it will give: Left type	Right type	OutputInteger	Integer	Integer Integer	Float	Float Float	Float	Float Non numeric	Integer	Null num numeric	Float	Null Non numeric	Non numeric	Null Only numeric inputs will return a result, otherwise it will return null.

searchDocs.title: SQL usage​
searchDocs.content: In SQL the subtract function is called using the minus operator: SELECT column1 - 13 FROM ...

searchDocs.title: Multiply​
searchDocs.content: Substrait definition Multipies two numbers. Multiply depends on the input types on what result it will give: Left type	Right type	OutputInteger	Integer	Integer Integer	Float	Float Float	Float	Float Non numeric	Integer	Null num numeric	Float	Null Non numeric	Non numeric	Null

searchDocs.title: SQL Usage​
searchDocs.content: SELECT column1 * 3 FROM ...

searchDocs.title: Divide​
searchDocs.content: Substrait definition Divide two numbers. Divide depends on the input types on what result it will give: Left type	Right type	OutputInteger	Integer	Float Integer	Float	Float Float	Float	Float Non numeric	Integer	Null num numeric	Float	Null Non numeric	Non numeric	Null There are some special cases when dividing with zero: 0 / 0 -> this results in NaN.PositiveNumber / 0 -> +InfinityNegativeNumber / 0 -> -Infinity

searchDocs.title: SQL Usage​
searchDocs.content: SELECT column1 / 3 FROM ...

searchDocs.title: Negate​
searchDocs.content: Substrait definition Negates a numeric value, example: 1 becomes -1-1 becomes 11.3 becomes -1.3 Non numeric values becomes 'null'.

searchDocs.title: SQL Usage​
searchDocs.content: SELECT -column1 FROM ...

searchDocs.title: Or​
searchDocs.content: Substrait definition Or implements the boolean logic Or operator. Its return value will always be a boolean. An argument into the Or function that is not a boolean will be the same as the boolean value false.

searchDocs.title: SQL Usage​
searchDocs.content: ... WHERE c1 = 'hello' OR c2 = 'world'

searchDocs.title: And​
searchDocs.content: Substrait definition And implements the boolean logic And operator. Its return value will always be a boolean. An argument into the And function that is not a boolean will be the same as the boolean value false.

searchDocs.title: SQL Usage​
searchDocs.content: ... WHERE c1 = 'hello' AND c2 = 'world'

searchDocs.title: Ceiling​
searchDocs.content: Substrait definition Rounds a number up to its closest integer. Its output type will always be an integer, if a non numeric type is passed in, the function will return null.

searchDocs.title: SQL Usage​
searchDocs.content: SELECT ceiling(column1) FROM ...  or SELECT ceil(column1) FROM ...

searchDocs.title: Floor​
searchDocs.content: Substrait definition Rounds a number down to its closest integer. Its output type will always be an integer, if a non numeric type is passed in, the function will return null.

searchDocs.title: SQL Usage​
searchDocs.content: SELECT floor(column1) FROM ...

searchDocs.title: Round​
searchDocs.content: Substrait definition Rounds a number to its closest integer. Its output type will always be an integer, if a non numeric type is passed in, the function will return null.

searchDocs.title: SQL Usage​
searchDocs.content: SELECT round(column1) FROM ...

searchDocs.title: Equal​
searchDocs.content: Substrait definition Compares equality of two values. If the two values have different types they are not considered equal, so a float with value 1 will not equal an integer with value 1.

searchDocs.title: SQL Usage​
searchDocs.content: ... WHERE c1 = 'hello'

searchDocs.title: Not equal​
searchDocs.content: Substrait definition Checks two values for non equality. Different types will immedietly return true, that the values are not equal.

searchDocs.title: SQL Usage​
searchDocs.content: ... WHERE c1 != 'hello'

searchDocs.title: Greater than​
searchDocs.content: Substrait definition Checks if the left value is greater than the right value.

searchDocs.title: SQL Usage​
searchDocs.content: ... WHERE c1 > 1

searchDocs.title: Greater than or equal​
searchDocs.content: Substrait definition Checks if the left value is greater than or equal to the right value.

searchDocs.title: SQL Usage​
searchDocs.content: ... WHERE c1 >= 1

searchDocs.title: Less than​
searchDocs.content: Substrait definition Checks if the left value is less than the right value.

searchDocs.title: SQL Usage​
searchDocs.content: ... WHERE c1 < 1

searchDocs.title: Less than or equal​
searchDocs.content: Substrait definition Checks if the left value is less than or equal to the right value.

searchDocs.title: SQL Usage​
searchDocs.content: ... WHERE c1 <= 1

searchDocs.title: Between​
searchDocs.content: Substrait definition Checks if an expression is between two values.

searchDocs.title: SQL Usage​
searchDocs.content: ... WHERE c1 BETWEEN 100 AND 200

searchDocs.title: Is not null​
searchDocs.content: Substrait definition Checks if a single argument is not equal to null.

searchDocs.title: SQL Usage​
searchDocs.content: ... WHERE c1 is not null

searchDocs.title: Coalesce​
searchDocs.content: Substrait definition Returns the first value, left to right that is not equal to null. If all values are null, a null value is returned.

searchDocs.title: SQL Usage​
searchDocs.content: SELECT coalesce(column1, column2) FROM ...

searchDocs.title: Is Infinite​
searchDocs.content: Substrait definition Checks if a numeric value is positive or negative infinite. If the value is NaN (0 / 0), or another type, it returns false.

searchDocs.title: SQL Usage​
searchDocs.content: SELECT is_infinite(column1) FROM ...

searchDocs.title: Is Finite​
searchDocs.content: Substrait definition Checks if a numeric value is not positive or negative infinite or NaN. If the value is not numeric it returns false.

searchDocs.title: SQL Usage​
searchDocs.content: SELECT is_finite(column1) FROM ...

searchDocs.title: Concat​
searchDocs.content: Substrait definition Concatinates two or more string values together. This function tries and convert non string values into the string type, example: Input	Type	Output'hello'	String	'hello' 13	Int	'13' 13.4	Float	'13.4' true	Bool	'true' If any argument is null, the return value will always be null.

searchDocs.title: SQL Usage​
searchDocs.content: SELECT c1 || ' hello ' || c2 FROM ...

searchDocs.title: If Expression​
searchDocs.content: Substrait definition An if statement, or in SQL language a case statement.

searchDocs.title: SQL Usage​
searchDocs.content: SELECT CASE WHEN c1 = 'hello' THEN 1 WHEN c1 = 'world' THEN 2 ELSE 3 END FROM ...

searchDocs.title: Creating a plan​
searchDocs.content: The first step is to create an execution plan, this can be be done with any substrait plan creator. But it is also possible to do it with SQL inside flowtide. This tutorial will only show how to create a plan with SQL. Add the following to your Program.cs:  var sqlBuilder = new SqlPlanBuilder(); sqlBuilder.Sql(@" CREATE TABLE testtable ( val any ); CREATE TABLE other ( val any ); INSERT INTO output SELECT t.val FROM testtable t LEFT JOIN other o ON t.val = o.val WHERE t.val = 123; "); var plan = sqlBuilder.GetPlan();

searchDocs.title: Setting up a read and write factory​
searchDocs.content: Each stream requires a factory that provides it with source and sink operators. These provide the actual implementation when talking with other sources. Some examples of sinks and sources are: MS SQLKafkaPostgres This example will add a connection for SQL Server: var factory = new ReadWriteFactory(); // Wildcard that all sources should use the following configuration factory.AddSqlServerSource("*", () => "Server={your server};Database={your database};Trusted_Connection=True;"); // Wildcard that all sinks will use this configuration factory.AddSqlServerSink("*", () => "Server={your server};Database={your database};Trusted_Connection=True;");

searchDocs.title: Running the stream​
searchDocs.content: Finally to run the stream we add the following code: builder.Services.AddFlowtideStream(b => { b.AddPlan(plan) .AddReadWriteFactory(factory) .WithStateOptions(new StateManagerOptions() { // This is non persistent storage, use FasterKV persistence storage instead if you want persistent storage PersistentStorage = new FileCachePersistentStorage(new FlowtideDotNet.Storage.FileCacheOptions() { }) }); });

searchDocs.title: Persistent storage​
searchDocs.content: The previous example does not use persistent storage, to use persistent storage, you can instead use the FasterKV storage: PersistentStorage = new FasterKvPersistentStorage(new FasterKVSettings<long, SpanByte>() { RemoveOutdatedCheckpoints = true, MemorySize = 1024 * 1024 * 128, PageSize = 1024 * 1024 * 16, LogDevice = Devices.CreateLogDevice("./data/persistent/log"), CheckpointDir = "./data/checkpoints" })  The stream will then be persistent between checkpoints.

searchDocs.title: Adding the UI​
searchDocs.content: If you want to add the UI to visualize the progress of the stream, add the following code after "var app = builder.Build();". app.UseFlowtideUI("/stream");

searchDocs.title: Full example​
searchDocs.content: Here is the full code example to get started:  var builder = WebApplication.CreateBuilder(args); var sqlBuilder = new SqlPlanBuilder(); sqlBuilder.Sql(@" CREATE TABLE testtable ( val any ); CREATE TABLE other ( val any ); INSERT INTO output SELECT t.val FROM testtable t LEFT JOIN other o ON t.val = o.val WHERE t.val = 123; "); var plan = sqlBuilder.GetPlan(); var factory = new ReadWriteFactory(); // Wildcard that all sources should use the following configuration factory.AddSqlServerSource("*", () => "Server={your server};Database={your database};Trusted_Connection=True;"); // Wildcard that all sinks will use this configuration factory.AddSqlServerSink("*", () => "Server={your server};Database={your database};Trusted_Connection=True;"); builder.Services.AddFlowtideStream(b => { b.AddPlan(plan) .AddReadWriteFactory(factory) .WithStateOptions(new StateManagerOptions() { // This is non persistent storage, use FasterKV persistence storage instead if you want persistent storage PersistentStorage = new FileCachePersistentStorage(new FlowtideDotNet.Storage.FileCacheOptions() { }) }); }); var app = builder.Build(); app.UseFlowtideUI("/stream"); app.Run();

searchDocs.title: Metrics export​
searchDocs.content: To export metrics information, you need to install the following nuget packages: OpenTelemetry.Extensions.HostingAzure.Monitor.OpenTelemetry.Exporter Next in your Program.cs add the following code: builder.Services.AddOpenTelemetry() .WithMetrics(builder => { builder.AddAzureMonitorMetricExporter(o => { o.ConnectionString = "{your connection string}"; }); builder.AddView((instrument) => { return new MetricStreamConfiguration() { Name = $"{instrument.Meter.Name}.{instrument.Name}" }; }); builder.AddMeter("flowtide.*"); });  Replace {your connection string} with your application insights connection string. This will then start uploading custom metrics to your Application Insights in Azure Monitor.

searchDocs.title: Health check export​
searchDocs.content: If you want to publish/export health check information, install the following nuget package: AspNetCore.HealthChecks.Publisher.ApplicationInsights Add the following to your Program.cs: builder.Services.AddHealthChecks() .AddFlowtideCheck() .AddApplicationInsightsPublisher("{your connection string}");  Replace {your connection string} with your application insights connection string. You should now see custom events being published to Application Insights with health check information.

searchDocs.title: Sample​
searchDocs.content: A sample application exist for both setups in github.

searchDocs.title: Statuses​
searchDocs.content: This section describes how the different stream statuses maps to the health check status: Stream Status	Health check status	DescriptionFailing	Unhealthy	Stream has crashed Running	Running	Operational Starting	Degraded	Starting is only reported when going from stopped -> running Stopped	Unhealthy	If a stream should be stopped, remove it from health check Degraded	Degraded	Reported if a operator is degraded, such as slow performance

searchDocs.title: Sample​
searchDocs.content: You can find a sample in github to see how it can be setup.

searchDocs.title: Metrics​
searchDocs.content: The Aggregate Operator has the following metrics: Metric Name	Type	Descriptionbusy	Gauge	Value 0-1 on how busy the operator is. backpressure	Gauge	Value 0-1 on how much backpressure the operator has. health	Gauge	Value 0 or 1, if the operator is healthy or not. info At this point, an aggregate operator will never be unhealthy. If there is a failure against the state, the stream will instead restart.

searchDocs.title: Metrics​
searchDocs.content: The Projection Operator has the following metrics: Metric Name	Type	Descriptionbusy	Gauge	Value 0-1 on how busy the operator is. backpressure	Gauge	Value 0-1 on how much backpressure the operator has. health	Gauge	Value 0 or 1, if the operator is healthy or not. info At this point, a filter operator will never be unhealthy.

searchDocs.title: Metrics​
searchDocs.content: The Normalization Operator has the following metrics: Metric Name	Type	Descriptionbusy	Gauge	Value 0-1 on how busy the operator is. backpressure	Gauge	Value 0-1 on how much backpressure the operator has. health	Gauge	Value 0 or 1, if the operator is healthy or not. events	Counter	How many events that pass through the operator. info At this point, a normalization operator will never be unhealthy. If there is a failure against the state, the stream will instead restart.

searchDocs.title: Merge-Join Operator​
searchDocs.content: The merge-join operator is a stateful operator that is implemented by two different B+ trees, one for each input source. The trees are sorted based on the keys used in the equality condition.

searchDocs.title: Metrics​
searchDocs.content: Metric Name	Type	Descriptionbusy	Gauge	Value 0-1 on how busy the operator is. backpressure	Gauge	Value 0-1 on how much backpressure the operator has. health	Gauge	Value 0 or 1, if the operator is healthy or not. events	Counter	How many events that pass through the operator. info At this point, a merge-join operator will never be unhealthy.

searchDocs.title: Block-Nested Join Operator​
searchDocs.content: The block-nested join operator is a stateful operator that is implemented using 2 persistent B+ trees, and two temporary B+ trees. The temporary trees fill up with data until a watermark is recieved in which they it performs the join operations. It does this to reduce the amount of I/O that has to be made when reading through the entire persisted dataset.

searchDocs.title: Metrics​
searchDocs.content: Metric Name	Type	Descriptionbusy	Gauge	Value 0-1 on how busy the operator is. backpressure	Gauge	Value 0-1 on how much backpressure the operator has. health	Gauge	Value 0 or 1, if the operator is healthy or not. info At this point, a block-nested join operator will never be unhealthy. If there is a failure against the state, the stream will instead restart.

searchDocs.title: Metrics​
searchDocs.content: The Set Operator has the following metrics: Metric Name	Type	Descriptionbusy	Gauge	Value 0-1 on how busy the operator is. backpressure	Gauge	Value 0-1 on how much backpressure the operator has. health	Gauge	Value 0 or 1, if the operator is healthy or not. events	Counter	How many events that pass through the operator. info At this point, a set operator will never be unhealthy. If there is a failure against the state, the stream will instead restart.

searchDocs.title: Metrics​
searchDocs.content: The Projection Operator has the following metrics: Metric Name	Type	Descriptionbusy	Gauge	Value 0-1 on how busy the operator is. backpressure	Gauge	Value 0-1 on how much backpressure the operator has. health	Gauge	Value 0 or 1, if the operator is healthy or not. events	Counter	How many events that pass through the operator. info At this point, a projection operator will never be unhealthy.

searchDocs.title: FasterKV storage​
searchDocs.content: FasterKV is persistent key value store built by Microsoft. It is the only storage solution available for Flowtide that will persist data between runs. FasterKV is highly configurable, and how you configure it will affect the performance of your stream. To configure your stream to use FasterKV storage, add the following to the builder: builder .WithStateOptions(new StateManagerOptions() { PersistentStorage = new FasterKvPersistentStorage(new FasterKVSettings<long, SpanByte>() { // Set the fasterKV configuration here ... }) });

searchDocs.title: Useful configuration options​
searchDocs.content: Property	DescriptionLogDevice	The log device that will write to storage MemorySize	How much memory FasterKV can use PageSize	how large a page is CheckpointDir	Where checkpoints should be stored CheckpointManager	Checkpoint manager, useful if using Azure Storage.

searchDocs.title: Storing to disk​
searchDocs.content: This is an example of a configuration to store to a disk. var baseDirectory = "/persistence/" builder.WithStateOptions(new StateManagerOptions() { // Set cache page count to reduce the memory usage CachePageCount = 10000, PersistentStorage = new FasterKvPersistentStorage(new FasterKVSettings<long, SpanByte>() { // Checkpoint directory CheckpointDir = $"{baseDirectory}/checkpoints", // A local file log device LogDevice = Devices.CreateLogDevice($"{baseDirectory}/log"), // Redice memory usage of fasterKV, to limit memory usage MemorySize = 1024L * 1024L * 64, // Page size PageSize = 1024 * 1024 * 16, }), TemporaryStorageOptions = new FileCacheOptions() { // Path where the temporary cache is stored DirectoryPath = $"./temp" } })

searchDocs.title: Storing to Azure Storage​
searchDocs.content: Storing the data in an Azure Storage requires a bit more configuration, especially a checkpoint manager. // Create azure storage device var log = new AzureStorageDevice(STORAGE_STRING, BASE_CONTAINER, "", "hlog.log"); // Create azure storage backed checkpoint manager var checkpointManager = new DeviceLogCommitCheckpointManager( new AzureStorageNamedDeviceFactory(STORAGE_STRING), new DefaultCheckpointNamingScheme($"{BASE_CONTAINER}/checkpoints/")); builder.WithStateOptions(new StateManagerOptions() { // Set cache page count to reduce the memory usage CachePageCount = 10000, PersistentStorage = new FasterKvPersistentStorage(new FasterKVSettings<long, SpanByte>() { CheckpointManager = checkpointManager, LogDevice = log, // Redice memory usage of fasterKV, to limit memory usage MemorySize = 1024L * 1024L * 64, // Page size PageSize = 1024 * 1024 * 16, }), TemporaryStorageOptions = new FileCacheOptions() { // Path where the temporary cache is stored DirectoryPath = $"./temp" } })

searchDocs.title: Temporary file cache storage​
searchDocs.content: This storage solution is useful when developing or running unit tests on a stream. All data will be cleared between each run, but it will be persisted to local disk to reduce RAM usage and allow you to run streams with alot of data. The implementation of this is using the same solution as the intermediate file cache solution where modified pages are stored between checkpoints. To configure your stream to use this storage solution, add the following to the stream builder: builder .WithStateOptions(new StateManagerOptions() { // This is non persistent storage, use FasterKV persistence storage instead if you want persistent storage PersistentStorage = new FileCachePersistentStorage(new FlowtideDotNet.Storage.FileCacheOptions() { DirectoryPath = "./tmp" }) });

searchDocs.title: Configuration​
searchDocs.content: Property	Default value	DescriptionDirectoryPath	./data/tempFiles	Path where the files will be stored

searchDocs.title: Storage solution​
searchDocs.content: The stream storage is built on a three tier architecture, there is the in memory cache, the local disk modified page cache, and the persistent data. A data page is fetched using the following logic:
